title: OnePlus 15 Review: Overkill Performance, Disappointing Cameras
content:
# OnePlus 15 Review: Overkill Performance, Disappointing Cameras

Let’s not bury the lead: the OnePlus 15 is, in many ways, an exceptional phone. It’s fast, it’s smooth, and it’s packed with so much “extra stuff” that it borders on overkill. But as with many OnePlus devices before it, there’s a catch—and this time, it’s a big one.

---

## Performance: A New Level of Overkill

OnePlus didn’t just give the OnePlus 15 a modest spec bump. They went all-in, turning what could have been a simple mid-cycle refresh into a performance powerhouse.

**Key Upgrades:**
- **Snapdragon 8 Elite Gen 5**: This chip is already legendary, offering 20–40% faster performance than its predecessor, record-setting multi-core scores, and clock speeds up to 4.6 GHz.
- **UFS 4.1 Storage**: Blazing-fast read and write speeds.
- **LPDDR5X Ultra RAM**: The base model comes with 12GB, while the upgraded version offers a staggering 16GB of LPDDR5X Ultra Plus RAM—something rarely seen in smartphones today.
- **Enhanced Cooling**: A massive vapor chamber keeps thermals in check, even under heavy loads.

If OnePlus had stopped here, the OnePlus 15 would already be a compelling upgrade. But they didn’t.

---

## Design & Durability: Built Like a Tank

The OnePlus 15 features a cleaner, more squared-off design than its predecessor. The camera module is centered, aligned perfectly with the OnePlus logo, and the entire device is finished in a uniform matte texture.

**Colors:**
- Matte Black
- Matte Sand
- Matte Violet

But the real story is durability. OnePlus applied a **micro-arch oxidation finish**, creating a ceramic coating on the metal frame and back. The result? A matte black that doesn’t just resist fingerprints—it resists scratches entirely.

> “This phone isn’t taking the damage, it’s doing the damage.”

Scratches that appear on the surface often turn out to be residue from other objects, easily wiped away thanks to the ceramic’s hardness (8–9 on the Mohs scale).

**IP Ratings:**  
The phone is certified for IP66, IP68, IP69, and IP69K—meaning it can survive submersion, high-pressure water jets, and even temperatures up to 80°C. It could probably survive a laundry cycle.

---

## Battery: No Compromises

OnePlus has taken battery life to an almost comical extreme:

- **7,300 mAh Silicon Carbon Battery** – nearly double the capacity of some flagships from just a few years ago.
- **Real-World Performance**: 7–8 hours of screen-on time is easily achievable. Some days ended with 50% battery remaining—enough for another full day.
- **Charging**: 80W wired charging in the U.S. (100W internationally), 50W wireless charging, and a charging brick included in the box.
- **Battery Health Features**: You can limit charging to 85% and still have more battery than a Galaxy S25 Ultra.

---

## Display & Gaming: Niche Excellence

The OnePlus 15’s display is a mixed bag:

- **Refresh Rate**: Up to 165 Hz, but only in supported games like *Call of Duty* or *Clash of Clans*. Otherwise, it operates between 1 Hz and 120 Hz.
- **Resolution**: Slightly lower than the OnePlus 13 (1272p vs. 1440p), though most users won’t notice.
- **Touch Sampling**: A dedicated touch response chip enables a **3,200 Hz sampling rate**—far beyond the 1,440–2,400 Hz typical of other flagships.

This is a display built for mobile gamers who can genuinely perceive the difference between 120 Hz and 165 Hz.

---

## The Downsides: Where OnePlus Stumbles

### The Alert Slider Is Gone
OnePlus has replaced the beloved alert slider with a single customizable button. While functional, it lacks the tactile satisfaction and at-a-glance utility of the original.

### Haptics: A Minor Downgrade
On paper, the haptic motor is less advanced than the OnePlus 13’s—but in practice, it’s still excellent.

### The Cameras: A Major Letdown
Here’s the real disappointment. Despite all the overkill in performance and build, the cameras are a step backward:

- **Primary Sensor**: The same 50MP sensor found in the $400 Honor 200. It struggles with noise in medium light and lacks detail.
- **Telephoto & Ultra-Wide**: A 3.5x telephoto and 116° ultra-wide round out the system, but both produce soft images with dull colors.
- **No More Hasselblad**: The partnership appears to be over. The orange shutter button, XPAN mode, and Hasselblad branding are gone.

> “In a world where they have done so much… once again on a OnePlus phone, the cameras are an area where you’ll have to be okay with being disappointed.”

---

## Software & Experience

Oxygen OS continues to resemble Color OS (and by extension, iOS), but it remains buttery smooth and highly customizable. AI features are optional, and system behaviors can be tweaked to your liking. It’s a confident, fast, and reliable software experience—just don’t expect stock Android purity.

---

## Final Thoughts

The OnePlus 15 is a phone of extremes:

✅ **Pros:**
- Unmatched performance and future-proof specs
- Incredible battery life
- Premium, durable design
- Competitive pricing ($899 for 12GB, $999 for 16GB)

❌ **Cons:**
- Disappointing camera system
- No alert slider
- Slightly lower display resolution

If you’re a mobile gamer, a power user, or someone who values battery life and raw speed above all else, the OnePlus 15 is a no-brainer. But if camera quality is a priority, you’ll need to look elsewhere.

OnePlus has once again delivered a phone that’s “not normal”—in both the best and most frustrating ways.
